user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of SHA1PadMessage:
```c
static void
SHA1PadMessage (struct SHA1Context *context)
{
  if (context->message_block_index > 55)
  {
    context->message_block[context->message_block_index++] = 0x80;
    while (context->message_block_index < 64)
    {
      context->message_block[context->message_block_index++] = 0;
    }
    SHA1ProcessMessageBlock (context);
    while (context->message_block_index < 56)
    {
      context->message_block[context->message_block_index++] = 0;
    }
  }
  else
  {
    context->message_block[context->message_block_index++] = 0x80;
    while (context->message_block_index < 56)
    {
      context->message_block[context->message_block_index++] = 0;
    }
  }
  context->message_block[56] = (unsigned char) (context->length_high >> 24);
  context->message_block[57] = (unsigned char) (context->length_high >> 16);
  context->message_block[58] = (unsigned char) (context->length_high >> 8);
  context->message_block[59] = (unsigned char) (context->length_high);
  context->message_block[60] = (unsigned char) (context->length_low >> 24);
  context->message_block[61] = (unsigned char) (context->length_low >> 16);
  context->message_block[62] = (unsigned char) (context->length_low >> 8);
  context->message_block[63] = (unsigned char) (context->length_low);
  SHA1ProcessMessageBlock (context);
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function SHA1PadMessage:
struct SHA1Context
{
  uint32_t intermediate_hash[SHA1HashSize / 4];
  uint32_t length_low;
  uint32_t length_high;
  int_least16_t message_block_index;
  unsigned char message_block[64];
  int computed;
  int corrupted;
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No code fragments in SHA1PadMessage are statically unreachable. The function’s control flow depends on the runtime value of context->message_block_index, so both branches of the if (context->message_block_index > 55) statement are reachable depending on that value. The while loops are conditional on the value of message_block_index at runtime (and on any changes made by SHA1ProcessMessageBlock), so they are not provably dead code. The final sequence that writes message_block[56]..[63] and calls SHA1ProcessMessageBlock always follows the earlier branches and is reachable. There are no return, break, goto, or constant-contradiction conditions that would make any of the shown statements impossible to execute.

Note: although no unreachable code was found, there are other potential issues (for example, possible out-of-bounds indexing if message_block_index has an unexpected value or signedness-related concerns). Those are not instances of unreachable code (MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1) and therefore are not reported here.
